content.description: A sketchy but easy first pitch followed by a hard, well-protected 5.8 pitch that's tough to the end.
content.location: Starting at the bottom of The Yellojacket Butress, climb straight up to a tree (belay).  Move left to a left facing corner that leads to a small roof.  Pull the roof and belay at the tree.  You can either rap or scramble off.

content.description: Climbs up the left side of the wall in a left-facing corner. Finishes at a funky curved forked tree.
Begin left of Deceptive about where it tops out. Climb a backward "C" shaped crack (to the right of Wasted). The crack curves left near the top but continue straight up the face to top out.

Follow the ever widening crack that flares out real wide (#6) at the top. Juggy moves and solid feet lead to a wide crack. The "rules" of this route are once you are to the proper off-width section you only use holds and jams inside the off-width. Feet are nice and fair game all over. Would likely go around 5.9 if you applied the same rules to the feet. Fun pitch, Worthy of a rip!Traverse left at the top for a great crack for a gear anchor, or top out onto an airy ledge with lots of loose blocks and extremely sharp edges. Walk off to the overlook or scamble down to the gully on climbers right at the top and rap off the pine trees with tat.
content.protection: standard rack plus #4, #5, and #6 all are useful, but not absolutely necessary.
content.location: This face is around the left side of Deceptive Buttress, you can't miss the wideness.Left of Surprise, Right of Blackwinter.

content.description: Begins on the right end of the wall just left of a tree. Climb up and a little right dealing with the tree. Keep going up the face near the arete. If you get out around the arete it gets too easy so stay left. When you get to a broad ledge with loos blocks keep going on the last 20 feet of Blackwinter.
content.protection: helmet, standard rack or top rope gear.

content.description: Climb the prominent left-rising crack system to a small blocky ledge. Climb straight upward to the roof capping the wall. Climb directly over the roof to an airy ledge. Scramble up and off.

climbs.name: Puyk
climbs.fa: Dru Marshall, Rob Savoye, Mark Pence Sept. 1983

content.description: Climb the prominent left-rising crack system to a small blocky ledge. Climb straight upward to the roof capping the wall. Climb around the left side of the roof to an airy ledge. Scramble up and off.
Start just left of a 6 inch wide ledge about 4 feet off the ground. Climb straight up the middle of the wall. It steepens near the top but your find a nice handjam in a horizontal
content.protection: Top rope anchors using gear or slings
content.location:
scramble up the Gully passing the start to Dee's Rival by about 15 ft, scramble up left through a ramp to gain a platform at the base of this wall 

  BABY BURN WALL

content.description: Climbs the obvious crack (flaring) 15 feet left and around a corner from a cedar tree. Climb up the left-facing corner to its end, continue upward taking a right-leaning crack up through a roof to the top.
Begin in the center of the wall at the right end of a ramp. Climb up to about where two cracks meet and head up left along a crack until you can access a main crack that goes to the top
Staying off of the right wall or corner (the rules), climb the finger crack to the top. Sees little traffic so it is a bit dirty.
content.location: Get to the ledge on top of the Yellowjacket Wall. Go left about 40 feet on grassy ledges until you get to a steep wall split by thin vertical crack net to a corner.

climbs.name: Coronacation
climbs.fa: Chris P and Phil M March 2020

content.description: Follow an ever widening crack that flares out real wide (#6) at the top. Juggy moves and solid feet lead to a vertical move or two. This route follows the crack but using face holds along the way. Tops out onto an airy ledge with lots of loose blocks and extremely sharp edges. Walk off to the overlook OR scramble down to the gully on climbers right at the top and rap off the pine trees with tat.
content.protection: Standard rack plus #4 and #6 to really protect the top well.
content.location: On the left side of the Deceptive Buttress. Right of blackwinter on the right side of the gulley. Left of Surprise/Deceptive.

content.description:
Follow an arete up and over a roof (crux one) to a pin and optional ball-nut placement. Move left to the arete (crux two) and continue climbing one of the best aretes in maryland.

 Use the anchors; topping out this route puts you right at the overlook. Keeping a low profile can only help access.
content.protection: A light rack favoring gear under one inch and draws to clip the four bolts, pin, and anchors.
content.location:
Starting at the bottom of the Pyuk Butress, climb a small, bad corner or scramble around to the base of the arete, where the good rock starts.

 It's best to appoach by going by the pillar and scrambling across a narrow traverse ledge to the base of the bad corner. Scramble around some more if you want to skip to the good climbing.

content.description: Climb up the left-facing overhaning corner to where it turns into a small roof. Climb over the roof and up the fractured line of rock left of a sheer face. When you hit a ledge 30 feet up, move right around an arete into a slightly overhanging  face on decent holds.
content.protection: helmet, standard rack or toprope anchors

content.description: Climb the thin crack when it runs out, continue up the black rock face on anorexic / thin holds leading to a slot. Move past a horizontal stepping left and pull the roof following the broken crack to the cedar tree directly above.
content.protection: Watch for loose rock particularly near the top of the climb and on the ledge.   A few more gear placements are available directly behind the tree and at the center of the left leaning crack just before it starts to flare.  However this makes for a very zig-zaging line and drops the ratting to R instead of X.
content.location:
The climb is located on the Yellow Jacket wall Starting up on the ledge just left of the large ceder tree.              

Topo: Names of the individual walls      .

content.description: Begin climbing Baby Burn but climb straight up the left side of the wall to the top, rather than trending rightward with the crack. There is a small overlap near the top to deal with.

Start on the left side of the wall at the right side of a small, foot wide ledge about 5 feet off the ground. Climb the most obvious thin crack rising rightward up to a large vertical crack. Climb straight up from there. The name comes from the first ascent happening mid-summer on a 100 degree day in the sun.

Start at the base of the arete and climb The Broadcast to the roof. At the roof, make a move or two towards the teardrop-shaped flake on your right. At the hollow teardrop flake, follow the seams that trend up and right to some easier rock where you can then gradually climb towards the anchor.
content.protection: A standard rack will do, be ready to extend a lot of the gear as it's fairly spread out as you're going over the roof.
content.location: It starts at the base of the Pyuk Butress.  You can scramble up past the pillar to get to a small traverse ledge that will take you to the bottom of the route.

content.description: A collection of short walls form 25 to 70 feet tall and one free standing pillar.  Some of the walls can be linked together to create a multi pitch climb to the top of the cliff.  There are some good routes here in this lesser visited section of Maryland heights, just beware some walls have loose rock and ledges can be bushy.
